name: Henry Blodget
text: As Richard Nixon headed towards impeachment in 1974, a handful of Republican congressmen did everything they could to defend him. But no one wound up going in the tank for him as much as Rep. Earl Landgrebe (R-IN).//t.co/OJPRIF8ORs

name: Henry Blodget
text: On election day a few months after Nixon's resignation -- in a rematch against the same opponent he'd beaten 55%-45% in the 1972 race -- Congressman Landgrebe went down in a humiliating 39%-61% loss. He had tied himself to Nixon and, sure enough, he wound up going down with him.

name: Henry Blodget
text: From that same piece, which came out in August 1974, when almost everyone else in the GOP had thrown in the towel: "I'm going to stick with my President even if he and I have to be taken out of this building and shot." Nixon resigned from office a day after that piece ran.

name: Henry Blodget
text: When the Watergate scandal broke, Landgrebe emerged as one of the more ridiculous defenders of the president. "Don't confuse me with facts," he said when the end drew near. "I've got a closed mind. I will not vote for impeachment."//t.co/O2FmwHSLy2

name: Henry Blodget

name: Henry Blodget
text: Yes, this is the story. It's a nice-sounding story. And ideally IPO will, in fact, be priced just below market value (10%-20%). But IPO pricing will have zero affect on company's ability to sell more stock. What affects that is fundamental performance and market conditions.//t.co/2xu08B7NM2
